content.description: Data were collected during an experiment that used two identical cars, car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, moving along a one-dimensional track. Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> moved toward and collided with stationary car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, and data were collected. The data collected just before and just after the collision are shown below. (All velocities are represented in <math alttext="meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> .)
content.question: <math alttext="V sub 0. Car 1." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn><mo>⁢</mo></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="V sub f. Car 1." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>r</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="V sub f. Car 2." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>c</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="7.7" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="15.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="3.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="24.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>24.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> What conclusion can be made about the data taken in this experiment?

choices.label: Car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was more massive than car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was more massive than car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The velocity measurements for car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> were lower than the car’s actual speed.
The velocity measurements for car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> were higher than the car’s actual speed.
The experiment was performed without error.

content.answer: Car <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was more massive than car <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
